section.name: s1
section.heading: Citation
section.content: These regulations may be cited as the Mental Health Regulations.

section.name: s1A
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these regulations, unless the context otherwise requires—
section.def: Hospital Authority (醫院管理局) means the Hospital Authority established by section 3 of the Hospital Authority Ordinance (Cap. 113);
postal article (郵遞品) has the meaning assigned to it by section 2 of the Post Office Ordinance (Cap. 98).

section.name: s2
section.heading: Forms
section.content: The forms set forth in the Schedule are prescribed for the purposes of the Ordinance.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Responsibility of medical superintendent
section.content: The medical superintendent of a mental hospital shall be responsible for the care and treatment of all patients in the mental hospital and for the maintenance of discipline and good order in the hospital.

subsection.content: A medical superintendent may refuse to permit a person other than a mental hospital visitor to visit a patient if he reasonably considers that the visit is likely to cause unnecessary distress to or adversely affect the treatment of the patient.

subsection.leadIn: A medical superintendent may refuse to permit a patient to make or to receive a telephone call at a mental hospital if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he reasonably considers that the telephone call is likely to cause unnecessary distress to or adversely affect the treatment of the patient;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he reasonably considers that the telephone call is likely to cause unnecessary distress to the person to whom the telephone call is made or to any other person, not being a person on the staff of the mental hospital; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person to whom the telephone call is made has given notice in writing to the medical superintendent requesting that a telephone call made to him by the patient should be disallowed.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Power to open and examine any postal article, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subregulation (2), a medical superintendent may open and examine—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any postal article or any other article or thing addressed to a patient which is sent to or left at a mental hospital;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any postal article or other article or thing intended to be sent by a patient.

subsection.leadIn: Subregulation (1) does not apply to any postal article or other article or thing intended to be sent by a patient to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Executive; (60 of 2000 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member of the Executive Council; (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member of the Legislative Council;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a member of a District Council; (L.N. 419 of 1996; 8 of 1999 s. 89)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a Justice of the Peace; (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a public officer; (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: a mental hospital visitor; (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the Hospital Authority; (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: the Mental Health Review Tribunal or its secretary; or (L.N. 419 of 1996)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: a solicitor acting for the patient. (L.N. 419 of 1996)

section.name: s5A
section.heading: Refusal to permit certain postal articles, etc. addressed to a patient to be delivered to that patient

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subregulation (2), a medical superintendent may refuse to permit any postal article or other article or thing addressed to a patient to be delivered to such patient if the medical superintendent reasonably considers that such postal article or other article or thing is likely to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cause unnecessary distress to or adversely affect the treatment of the patient; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause danger to any person.

subsection.content: A medical superintendent shall not exercise the power conferred by subregulation (1) in respect of any postal article or other article or thing addressed to a patient by any of the persons or bodies specified in regulation 5(2) except with the prior consent of the person or body.

section.name: s5B
section.heading: Refusal to permit certain postal articles, etc. intended to be sent by a patient to leave the mental hospital

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subregulation (2), a medical superintendent may refuse to permit any postal article or other article or thing intended to be sent by a patient to leave the mental hospital if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person to whom such postal article or other article or thing is addressed has given notice in writing to the medical superintendent requesting that such should not be sent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the medical superintendent reasonably considers that such postal article or other article or thing is likely to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: cause danger to any person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: cause unnecessary distress to the person to whom it is addressed or to any other person, not being a person on the staff of the mental hospital.

subsection.content: Subregulation (1) does not apply to any postal article or other article or thing intended to be sent to any of the persons or bodies specified in regulation 5(2).

section.name: s5C
section.heading: Power to delete any part of a letter

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subregulation (2), a medical superintendent may, in the case of a letter, delete any part of it if he reasonably considers that such part if not deleted would be likely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the letter is addressed to a patient, to cause unnecessary distress to or adversely affect the treatment of the patient;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the letter is intended to be sent by a patient, to cause unnecessary distress to the person to whom it is addressed or to any other person, not being a person on the staff of the mental hospital; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to cause danger to any person.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any letter intended to be sent by a patient to any of the persons or bodies specified in regulation 5(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any letter addressed to a patient by any of the persons or bodies specified in regulation 5(2) except with the prior consent of the person or body.

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any postal article or other article or thing addressed to a patient is not delivered to the patient under regulation 5A, or any part of a letter addressed to a patient is deleted under regulation 5C, the medical superintendent shall within 7 days after exercising the power conferred under regulation 5A or 5C (as the case may be) give notice of the fact to the patient and to the sender of the postal article or other article or thing (if known); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any postal article or other article or thing intended to be sent by a patient is not permitted to leave the mental hospital under regulation 5B, or any part of a letter intended to be sent by the patient is deleted under regulation 5C, the medical superintendent shall within 7 days after exercising the power conferred under regulation 5B or 5C (as the case may be) give notice of the fact to the patient and to the person or body to whom the postal article or other article or thing is addressed.

section.name: s5E
section.heading: Return of postal articles, etc. to sender

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: in the case specified in regulation 5D(b), return such postal article or other article or thing to the patient.

section.name: s5F
section.heading: Power to open any postal article, etc. includes power to open anything contained therein, etc.
section.content: The powers conferred on a medical superintendent by regulations 5, 5A, 5B and 5E in relation to postal articles or other articles or things apply to anything contained in or forming part of such postal articles or other articles or things.

subsection.content: No patient may execute a document without the prior permission of a medical superintendent.

A medical superintendent may withhold permission under this regulation if he reasonably considers that the patient is of such unsound mind that he is incapable of understanding the legal implications of the execution of the document.

A medical superintendent may employ a patient on such work in a mental hospital as the medical superintendent reasonably considers to be appropriate or desirable having regard to the patient’s treatment.
Nothing in subregulation (1) shall be construed as conferring a power on a medical superintendent to compel a patient to work.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Restriction on possession by patient of certain articles or things

subsection.leadIn: A medical superintendent may search a patient or anything in the possession of the patient if he reasonably considers that the patient has in his possession any article or thing which is likely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to cause unnecessary distress to or adversely affect the treatment of the patient or any other patient; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to cause danger to any person.

subsection.content: A medical superintendent may confiscate or remove from a patient any article or thing found in his possession which the medical superintendent reasonably considers is such as is referred to in subregulation (1)(a) or (b).

section.name: s9
section.heading: Restriction on receipt by patient of certain articles or things

subsection.content: A medical superintendent may direct that a patient is not to receive any article or thing, or that any article or thing is not to be given to a patient, if the medical superintendent reasonably considers that the patient is of such unsound mind that he is incapable of looking after, handling or using the article or thing properly.

subsection.leadIn: A person who in contravention of a direction given under subregulation (1) knowingly—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: conveys to any patient; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sends to, brings to, throws into or otherwise deposits in the premises of a mental hospital,

subsection.continued: any article or thing with a view to its coming into the possession of any patient, commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 1.

subsection.content: Any article or thing conveyed, sent, brought, thrown or deposited in contravention of a direction given under subregulation (1) may be confiscated by a medical superintendent, whether or not a person has been convicted of an offence in connection with the contravention.

If a medical superintendent reasonably suspects that a person who is visiting a mental hospital has any article or thing in his possession with intent to contravene subregulation (1), he may require that person to be searched.
Nothing in subregulation (4) authorizes the searching of a person other than by a person of the same sex.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Prohibition of entry into a mental hospital
section.content: Any person who enters a mental hospital without lawful authority or excuse shall be guilty of an offence and on summary conviction shall be liable to a fine at level 1.
